newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast Lt. crudes edged lower, Mesa bought.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast Lt. crudes edged lower, Mesa bought.

text.p: U.S. West Coast light crudes edged lower Thursday with benchmark West Texas Intermediate (WTI) while interest of regional crudes remained thin amid talk of more foreign buys, traders said.
Traders said Atlantic Richfield Co (ARCO) recently bought two 400,000 barrel cargoes of Mesa crude, a lookalike to Alaska North Slope (ANS).
Venezuelan producers will load the cargoes in early June and deliver them to ARCO's Los Angeles refinery 10 to 15 days later.
Meanwhile, prices for ANS crude have remained stagnant since last week's sale of two cargoes at lower discounts.
ANS traded for $1.50 under West Texas Intermediate/Cushing crude, the U.S. benchmark grade.
BP, the biggest producer of ANS, continued to offer ANS at $1.30 under WTI, its price since Monday.
The unchanged discounts and five-cent fall on WTI trimmed outright ANS prices to $19.70/19.90 a barrel.
Kern River crude prices remained flat after Monday's rise in postings, to $14.50/14.60 a barrel.
Line 63 markets remained idle, while asphalt crude Wilmington rose with postings to $16.35/16.45.
